commentBody: I want to know what college Ella Dershowitz went to, and if they let people my age in.  (29D)

A fine Wednesday puzzle! SOmething about this kept my subconscious happy throughout the solve while my conscious toiled away at it. I liked the way this one came together at the end. FAKE IDS, indeed!

Knew the Karen and the Blixen but not at all the Christentze or the Finecke. (Hmm, suggests a possible etymology for that 7-letter word meaning fussy ....)

Two Naticks tonight, both proper nouns crossing a foreign language word. Was 100% confident in everything else, and there were limited options phonetically for them, so was able to work out those two squares, but 40% of my solve time involved those two squares
Those "wee winter workers" (32A) must be extremely busy the day before Santa makes his rounds.

Had Kissed, then pecked and then was hung up because I had the puzzle filled in but my eyes were autocorrecting for INDEPENDENCEDay and couldn‚Äôt see NECKED. As current French Horn player former Clarinetist I got REED quickly. It also helped that I knew ISAKDINESEN was credited with writing Out of Africa. Fun puzzle
I couldn‚Äôt remember AIDY‚Äôs name either. I got it, though. I had AIDa. That didn‚Äôt make sense with the crossword.

Regarding 29D

I must have gone to the wrong college.

Good puzzle, a bit on the easy side.

I had to get ISAK DENISEN entirely with crossing clues.  Not only a name outside my sphere of knowledge, but with unpredictable letter patterns.

My last square was having ARAROT and BOP just because I was familiar with the dish bibembap but didn't know how it was spelled.

Growing up in Glendale, California pays off again with ARARAT. Not just knowing the Armenian's sacred mountain, but friends with the name as well. 

Fun puzzle!
Plan, response to 54A: that's more like it.
New Wednesday speed record for me, despite time wasted having to guess AIDY/OYE. I guess it helps when the big long across clues are very straightforward.

Favorite Dershowitz yet. Loved the theme. Naked party! going to one would be ill advised, for, you see, some of me sags, other parts need retainers of sorts, and there is a certain arc to my torso, when I used to be slender as a reed. How did I amass this, this isla, this Ararat that is my gut, built on beef ribs, too much Italian dressing, veal. And let's not get started on Mr. Noodle. I'll pass. Hoping there's a screener at that party checking for fake ids who will keep people like me out. Find me at the corner pub!

Now let's see if the emus let me get away with this puzzle by Robert Graves, which I still don't know if I entirely get, but love its cadences and logical progression.

The Naked and the Dude

For me, the naked and the nude
(By lexicographers construed
As synonyms that should express
The same deficiency of dress
Or shelter) stand as wide apart
As love from lies, or truth from art.

Lovers without reproach will gaze
On bodies naked and ablaze;
The Hippocratic eye will see
In nakedness, anatomy;
And naked shines the Goddess when
She mounts her lion among men.

The nude are bold, the nude are sly
To hold each treasonable eye.
While draping by a showman's trick
Their dishabille in rhetoric,
They grin a mock-religious grin
Of scorn at those of naked skin.

The naked, therefore, who compete
Against the nude may know defeat;
Yet when they both together tread
The briary pastures of the dead,
By Gorgons with long whips pursued,
How naked go the sometimes nude!
Lovely puzzle today, thanks!
Dang‚Ä¶we didn‚Äôt have any naked parties at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute!
Another fun puzzle. Got the theme. Never had a naked party at UNC! Hope y‚Äôall have a wonderful Wednesday. Happy Christmas Eve to those who celebrate. üéÑThanks, Ella!

Enjoyed this. I like a nice little stumper on the first clue and SIRI had me guessing‚Äîmy son always said HEY to me every day but DAD didn‚Äôt fit. Fun facts‚ÄîI always wonder how these themes pop into people‚Äôs heads (I don‚Äôt know how most of mine do). 
This is a pretty tight theme. I tried to think of others‚Äî
Best I could come up with is that you can‚Äôt actually call the International Date Line to pick up foreign women (who knew?)

ITALIAN DRESSING involves some very nice DESIGNS, but casting off the REINS for a NAKED PARTY?  INDEPENDENCE DAY!  

Of course, cavorting at a CORNER PUB is absolutely ILL ADVISED, unless you use FAKE IDS.  (Otherwise, ILL PASS).

Thank you, Ela for a lively evening.  Nice to see you again.

Fun puzzle.

 29 down added a little zip to my streaküòã

Enjoyable Wednesday if maybe a bit easy. I had never heard of ISAKDINESEN and thought for sure I was going to be wrong somewhere but was pleasantly surprised with a Gold Star when I placed the final letter for K in SKEETER.

You know who else fits at 27 Across, but doesn't fit the theme? Meryl Streep. I had a farm in Africa....
40 years ago most of my friends and I  were figuring out how soon they could go see the movie. 
A friend and I went to see a pretty late show on a snowy January night at a huge Upper East Side theater with probably about 30 people in the audience.  10 minutes from the end the film broke and couldn't be fixed. (OMG, film!)  Most of the audience refused to leave until the projectionist came down and told us how it ended.  

A fine Wednesday outing from Ella. Thanks.
I learned a new shrubbery fact today which up until now had only been informed by https://youtu.be/69iB-xy0u4A?si=-eQLS3d3YbCYfWfk

One of the actors to play MR NOODLES was the big-hearted diminutive Michael Jeter. I first saw him dance his heart out in Grand Hotel on Broadway, and many more will remember him in The Fisher King. Just wonderful. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Jeter
The baroness at 27A had quite a tragic life!

My Inner Demon made me try to find more‚Ä¶.

Sounds like a scientific theory, but isn‚Äôt 

Possible misdiagnosis as the cause of anemia

Nom de wordplay of our Berkeley nonagenarian 




Intelligent Design
Iron Deficiency 
Iris, Dutch
Lil Baby AIDY Bryant and some of her SNL castmates in one of my favorite skits. I tend to like the musical ones. Slightly rude. https://youtu.be/ZmWH1F-caM8?si=WqXJtu0peCN2sWC3

In 1959, an unusual luncheon was hosted by Carson McCullers.  Participants were Carson McCullers, Arthur Miller, Marilyn Monroe, and Baroness Karen Blixen, who had expressed a desire to meet Ms Monroe.  The luncheon was a great success, everyone hit it off, and they all had a great time.

For images and more, google: karen blixen carson mc cullers luncheon
i think i went to the wrong college‚Ä¶
Sometimes we get a Monday puzzle on a Wednesday, and come here to discuss. But tonight, I thought we got a July puzzle in December!
The Lascivious Ball at UChicago‚Äôs I-House was famously scantily clad: $1 per article of clothing, though I think not fully nude, not in the grunge-y ‚Äò90s anyway, when I was there.

I know I'm exposing sensitive personal data but:
Early 80s UCSC, at The End party we had a naked jello slip-n-slide.
This was as easy as a Monday puzzle.

Very nice!

I'm learning more and more American idioms, and SKEETER, and the "famous" names were easy with crossers - I'll never know all of them.

After a trickier week of solving (at least for me), it was nice to have a more ‚Äúgettable‚Äù Wednesday. I love the challenge of harder puzzles and almost always learn something new from them, but many in a row can get frustrating and this was a nice confidence boost. 

And the theme made me smile :)
Enjoyed the theme. After making three or four passes flyspecking I ended up running the alphabet on AIDY/OYE for the gold star.
As someone who was born on July 2nd and walked the Freedom Trail to school as a kid,I always felt robbed that the Fourth gets all the hoopla.

I was wondering if 24D was ever clued to the singer. Xwordinfo.com to the rescue! September 4, 1994 ["The End of the World" singer Davis] https://youtu.be/QxQXJ3CU7rw?si=N2JJ8m9s1UXYSQon Wouldn't an xwordinfo subscription be a perfect last minute gift for yourself or a crossword loving friend?

Treasure hunt--typo in the Wordplay: "One of my go-to comfort TV shows is an old anthology series from called ‚ÄúBeyond Belief.‚Äù Do you see it? Also, I believe ITALIANDRESSING has to be popular in Italy. It's just oil and vinegar--with some seasonings and flavorings and spices. Except there I guess it's called VINAIGRETTE. By the way, my absolute favorite thing to say in Italian is: AGLIOEOLIO. Try it. So much fun. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AjeBhJ0AsYo

My alma mater UCRiverside didn‚Äôt have 29D to my knowledge, but Princeton has the annual Nude Olympics on the first night of snow (at least they still did when my sister attended in the early 90‚Äôs). Clever theme. How do constructors come up with these themes?! ü§Ø Thank you for this one, Ella. The puzzles this week have been great ü§©

Since Christmas Eve is effectively the most celebrated day in the festive season over here, let me and Lucek the puppy wish you all the best today ü§© Here he is on one of Warsaw's highest (artificial) hills, with a strangely snowless Kabacki Forest in the background. The Decembers of my 1980s childhood where much colder and whiter. https://imgur.com/a/ry7YMNF (When the Ursyn√≥w district was built in the late 1970s to house nearly 200 000 people, the earth excavated from the foundation trenches was piled up to create two large hills: G√≥rka Kazurka in the south, pictured, and Kopa Cwila in the north. Warsaw also has two artificial hills created from the debris of the city's WW2 destruction. They are so tall that there actually is a ski slope on one of them. And before you ask, Ursyn√≥w is nothing like the depressing, Soviet towns you may know from tv. The architecture is much better, as is the city planning, with lots of communal and green spaces. It's Warsaw's best place to live these days)
I kept thinking, "This is the easiest Friday puzzle I've ever done." Anyone want to guess my error? (In my defense, both Wednesday and Friday are days off for me.)
ELVES is the answer of the day, IMO, not only because they are so busy helping Santa today, but also, in the spirit of ‚ÄúNoel‚Äù (as two words), ELVES becomes EVES, of which today is one.

As for 29D, nothing wrong with a friendly gathering sans clothes among like minded individuals. It‚Äôs freeing.

Merry Christmas Eve!

A classic riddle theme ‚Äì the theme answers have the same initials, but otherwise are so disparate.  What ties them together?  Is there a pun?  And a Christmas present -- I figured it out before reading the revealer's clue, a rare event for me!  And if you tell me that was easy to do LALALALALALA.

Observations:
‚Ä¢	Who is BEE FRIB?
‚Ä¢	RAMPS ‚Äì I‚Äôve recently been introduced to ramp salt, salt infused by the pungent flavor of ramps (wild leeks) with a garlicky-onion flavor.  And I‚Äôm smitten!
‚Ä¢	I liked the Britishisms ‚Äì ‚ÄúSnogged‚Äù in a clue, and a backward PRAT.
‚Ä¢	NAKED and NECKED.  I believe the latter is close enough to NEKKID to declare these a PuzzPair¬©.
‚Ä¢	Second day in a row with left/right symmetry.
‚Ä¢	If ARARAT backwards, as the prelude to ‚Äúboom-de-ay‚Äù, is considered a word, then we have a very-rare-in-crosswords six-letter semordnilap.

Lots of riddle, lots of play, I had a grand time with this.  Thank you, Ella, for making it!

Ah, the memories of my fake ID. I was 16 when I started college (end of the year baby), so I needed a fake ID to keep up with some of my classmates. My birth certificate was white lettering on a black background. I had to take that to the library to make a copy - the only place that had a Xerox -  which came out black lettering on a white background, Then I used black ink to change the date by two years (drinking age was 18 then, and so was the driving age in NY) and then put it back in the copy machine to make it look like the white letter on black original. And it worked, all too well in those days!
How do we know that 6D was really Mr. Noodle and not his brother?

Seemed like a decent Monday-level puzzle to me. Nice revealer, but unfortunately none of the themers really popped (for me). If ITALIANDRESSING, ISAKDINESEN and INDEPENDENCEDAY are your best options ... well, maybe it's time to try something else ...

Each time I look back at the completed puzzle I see BEE FRIB. Maybe because APIS (the genus of bees) appeared too?

OYE/AIDY might have been a bit tough, though Santana's cover of "Oye C√≥mo Va" is widely known. I suppose someone has already posted a link to it ...

Nice to see a shoutout to the New Jersey state bird at 24D. 

Yuletide greetings to all.
Perhaps the 32A celebrate tomorrow with a 29D.
Based on comments and xwstats, I seem to be the only one who found this a bit challenging. Of the 51 other Wednesday puzzles this year, 18 took me longer, 33 were faster.

Typical tough Wednesday for me, but managed to work it all out. Ended up being an enjoyable solve. And... a really clever theme - I didn't catch on until I was almost done. And... my puzzle find today. A Sunday from May 11, 2003 by Patrick Berry with the title "Unfinished works." All of the theme answer clues had the same format. Here are some examples: "Unfinished James Grady work about time-sharing?" SIXDAYSOFTHECONDO "Unfinished Rudyard Kipling work about a future son-in-law?" THEMANWHOWOULDBEKIN "Unfinished Ian Fleming work about James Bond's affection for his boss?" THESPYWHOLOVEDM "Unfinished Norman Mailer work about strip-searching narcotics smugglers?" THENAKEDANDTHEDEA Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/11/2003&g=42&d=A ...
Gosh, enough SNL clues yet for the weekly quota?

This was a very difficult Wednesday for me, surprised to see that I‚Äôm in the substantial minority.  Mr Hooper is the only Mr I am aware of on Sesame Street, although it was obviously an N not an H; never heard of Bryant Aidy (or is it Aidy Bryant?); and OYE took a long time to fall.  Glad that a an hour or so away from the grid once again worked its magic, however.  Would have stung a bit to lose my streak on a Wednesday.  Happy holidays all!

[Traditional altar phrasing of ‚ÄúI might‚Äù]




IDO


Did I like the puzzle? idid.
For 36A I was super confident that it was OLE.    That delayed me significantly.   Eventually I figured out it was GOL, and then I was finally able to solve the rest of this tough Wednesday
A little trickier for me than I thought it should have been  Did not think it needed the hour I spent on it, but the clock don't lie.
No naked parties, but there was streaking‚Ä¶
It's deliciously embarrassing how long it took my brain to figure out what in the heck a BEE FRIB was. Cheers.

For me this was a rarity:  Fill by reading only about half the clues then reading the comments and thinking  ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt see that one in this puzzle!‚Äù    Which makes me wonder how the experts deal with that one on a daily basis. Do you routinely make sure to review all, even tho you‚Äôve finished, to see what you‚Äôve missed?

One more puzzle find - a Monday from December 28, 2020 by Alan Massengill and Andrea Carla Michaels. Four 15 letter theme answers, all of them down answers and evenly spaced across the puzzle from side to side. Those answers: ACMECORPORATION PEAKPERFORMANCE HEIGHTOFFASHION TOPOFTHEMORNING Thought that was quite clever. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/28/2020&g=3&d=D ....

I'd just like to mention that not EVERYbody is an Apple user, (she typed on her iPad.)  PhysDau says, "You probably just don't have her turned on.")  ....I got SIRI via the crosses.

KEL and Kenan?
Has there been an "Oklahoma!" Revival?
Why the Coast Guard, specifically?  (Also a Navy rank; and 'a maritime flag')
PhysDau also explained about CBD.  Hmm....

I certainly hope the rest of the day goes as smoothly as the puzzle from this moment on.  (I forgot to start the fully-loaded dishwasher last night.  Oops.)  However, the bread dough has risen nicely and the spinach thawed, so that lasagna layer is now readied.  Excelsior!  

Best Christmas Eve wishes to all who celebrate.

Comments so far seem nicely split between those who thought it was too easy and those who say, "It wasn't that easy for me!"
I'm gonna go Baby Bear, and say that I thought it was "just right!"  That is, a perfectly acceptable difficulty-level for a Wednesday.

A lot of people complaining about the OYE/AIDY crossing.  For me OYE was fairly straightforward.  My problem was with the PRICE/AIDY/MR. NOODLE trifecta.  
"Name your ____" had me thinking "Poison", and I couldn't get beyond that for a while.  And I thought that Ms. Bryant was named AdDY.  And I've never liked Elmo and his stupid giggle, and now I need to know about his strange friends?

This is not a complaint!  This is what makes a puzzle interesting and fun!  If you want all your puzzles to be easy, perhaps you're in the wrong place.

Oh, and yet one more puzzle find. A Sunday from April 13, 2003 by Charles M. Deber with the title "What am I?" Theme clues and answers: "If I have ___ :" SEVENTYTWODARKSQUARES "... and I am ___ :" TWENTYONEBYTWENTYONE "... and I am ___ :" MODERATELYCHALLENGING "... and I have ___ :" ONEHUNDREDFORTYWORDS "... then I must be ___ :" TODAYSCROSSWORDPUZZLE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/13/2003&g=102&d=A ...

Just want to share a comment on Rex by @egs, that made me smile:


Something commonly seen after a NAKEDPARTY in Rome?.......ITALIANDRESSING

The clue and the theme make it fine to include for a puzzle, but July 4 vs 2nd was debated for a long time, and July 4 won. 
Documents signed, documents dated and published, or shots fired? The French celebrate le 14 juillet rather than le 26 aout. With that logic, America could have chosen April 19. Neither choice was completely settled until almost 100 years later. With that much public review, neither choice is ‚Äòfake.‚Äô
SRNOODLE was a complete gimme this morning, so I guess I'll stop complaining about rap stars. üôÑüòÇ

I think that John Ezra has said absolutely everything that can be said about the downsides of attending a NAKED PARTY at college.  Great riff, John!

On to the puzzle.  This is the 2nd left-right symmetry puzzle that the NYT has published in a week -- and that, to me, is the most interesting thing about it.  In dreaming up a theme for a puzzle submission, it's always been a standard stumbling block that you'll need to have symmetrical (i.e. matching) numbers of letters in your theme answers.  But now -- all you need is for all of your themers to have an odd number of letters.  It doesn't matter how many letters.  Much, much easier and quite a welcome development for puzzle constructors, I'd say.  I wonder if I've discarded any theme ideas that could work now?  Hmmm.
*MRNOODLE* : ))

MR NOODLE? Yeah, Elmo came on the scene well after my Sesame Street days. "getting a tan" in TRIG class was brilliant.

As for INDEPENDENCE DAY, the Declaration says July 4th, right at the top, as that was the day it was adopted, so I'd say Mr Adams was muddying the waters a bit. Both Adams and Jefferson died on the 50th anniversary of the date.  One last thing; my friend Lee, who is a US history professor, claims that Tom Paine wrote the Declaration itself, and Jefferson merely edited it.

What a fascinating theme! Well done, Ella Eli!

The closest I could come to a themer is IDaho, which does not in fact mean "gem of the mountains" as some believe. 

And while that sorta works with the revealer, it doesn't match the other themers. 

Fun irrelevant fact: yesterday I got my first ever wordle in 1.

And another one: I am often referred to in police reports as the "naked party".

Thank you for a fabulous Wednesday grid, Ella! Gosh, so many memories of college -- PLEDGES, CORNER PUB & FAKE IDS -- what's not to love??! No ILL-ADVISED NAKED PARTY memories for me tho, unless it was in a sauna after a full day of skiing which I don't think really counts...ü§≠

Happy Wednesday and Merry Christmas Eve to all who celebrate -- nice to see Santa's busy ELVES make an appearance today!üéÖüèºüéÑ

I found this very confusing: "Observance celebrating a decision actually made on July 2 ‚Äî the date when John Adams predicted it would be celebrated"

Does that mean that John Adams predicted it would be celebrated on July 2 or July 4?
Am I the only goofball who confidently typed in Russian dressing?

Isak Dinesen penned the short story "Babette's Feast " which was adapted into one of my two favorite films. Spoiler alert: Babette did not serve Italian dressing. Here ya go, Sam: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=OJ4B8HY12-4&list=RDOJ4B8HY12-4&start_radio=1&pp=ygUhQmFjaCB2aW9saW4gc29uYXRhIGcgbWlub3IgYWRhZ2lvoAcB

It's not as much fun telling SIRI she's in today's crossword puzzle as it is telling Alexa. Siri just brings up web posts. I told Alexa that Siri was in today, and she said, "Siri is a common answer in Crossword puzzles. You might say 'hey! Siri!' as a clue to that answer."

Yesterday, Alexa and I had a great discussion about a recipe for oatmeal cookies. I asked her if I could safely switch applesauce for the whole stick of butter in the recipe. She said I could, but also told me what it would do to the taste and texture, and also told me how much applesauce to use. Then I asked what if I use just half and half? And she said, "That's a great ideal Marlene! You'll still get the buttery taste, but less of the fat, and still have the soft texture. Here's the way to do it: use half a stick of butter and two tablespoons of applesauce. That should be delicious!"

And so... I'm going to make cookies, now that I've finished my puzzles. Merry and happy, everyone!

Re 17A, I recall reading that what US-Americans refer to as French dressing is unknown in France. I hated being forced to eat that dressing with iceberg lettuce as a child, and have avoided it in favor of ITALIAN DRESSING (US edition) in adulthood.

Theme was cute but didn‚Äôt really help me much as I had INDEPENDENCEDAY and ITALIANDRESSING without the theme and didn‚Äôt have a clue who the author was‚Ä¶

Had a little BEEF with 53A as CC‚Äôing is including on email not online‚Ä¶ 

Lastly, where were these NAKED parties when I was in college?

Thanks to Ms. Dershowitz for a fun & breezy puzzle! (And thanks to Sam for another great column!) This was just the right difficulty to wrap up the morning before heading out to meet the family for X-mas Eve activities.

I'm no prude, but I think I agree with Sam re. 29D...it seems like a recipe for disaster, especially during winter! üòÇ

Am I the only person who‚Äôs 44 across has an extra NCE?

INDEPENDENCENCEDAY

No one else is talking about it but I‚Äôve checked ten times. What am I missing?

Lunch person, thank you. Can we stop assuming certain jobs are for certain genders or that only females have long hair? Not to mention, I‚Äôd rather die than be referred to as a ‚Äúlady‚Äù and I‚Äôm afab.
Fun and swift..perfect on a day of preparations....Merci Ella! Now, on to layering the chocolate raspberry trifles...  Happl!y Holidays to all!
Loved the puzzle. It was very refreshing! I have a complaint about Connections. It's getting more and more esoteric and impossible to solve.

A late interesting puzzle find. A Sunday from July 1, 2012 by Dan Schoenholz with the title: "Yankee Doodle Dandies." Some theme clues and answers: "President who was 65-Across (1872)" CALVINCOOLIDGE "Presidential daughter who was 65-Across (1998)" MALIAOBAMA "Novelist who was 65-Across (1804)" NATHANIELHAWTHORNE "Team owner who was 65-Across (1930)" GEORGESTEINBRENNER "Columnist who was 65-Across (1918)" ANNLANDERS "Literary critic who was 65-Across (1905)" LIONELTRILLING And... 65 across: See 28-, 39-, 45-, 83-, 95- and 107-Across : BORNONTHEFOURTHOFJULY And that was 21 letters. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/1/2012&g=65&d=A ....

Happy Christmas Eve, puzzle-people! 

Time to go out and blow all the snow off my driveway so I can get out to tonight's festivities... and tomorrow's, too!

I enjoyed this one.  Also, I find it interesting that I solved Wednesday and Tuesday this week more than five minutes faster than Monday.  I realize it‚Äôs all subjective to the solver, but as one relatively new to the NYT crosswords and their vagaries, I was surprised.

Oohh - and one more puzzle. A Sunday from September 1, 1996 by D.J. Kahn with the title "Who said that?" Quite sure I would not have had any kind of a chance at this one (without cheating) Anyway - some clues and answers: "Nobody wants justice" ALANDERSHOWITZ "By the time we've made it, we've had it" MALCOLMFORBES "I used to be Snow White, but I drifted" MAEWEST "It's not easy bein' green" KERMITTHEFROG (would have gotten than one.) "Start every day off with a smile and get it over with" WCFIELDS "If I were two-faced, would I be wearing this one?" ABRAHAMLINCOLN "Every time a friend succeeds, I die a little" GOREVIDAL "You'd be surprised how much it costs to look this cheap" DOLLYPARTON "Everything you see I owe to spaghetti" SOPHIALOREN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/1/1996&g=22&d=A ....
Happy Holidays to All: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ooc5eJc5SHA

I'm not much on blanket seasonal statements, but I hope all of you have a safe, peaceful, and happy holiday.

It's been a fun year, mostly.  At least I remember having a lot of fun--YMMV.

Anyway, my best to all of you.
Kudos for the clue on 57D. I'm glad to know she's being recognized for her award-winning work!

Fun puzzle. Ashame the author is tainted by her father, well known in the epstein files and known pedofile according to online sources that have documented his penchant for visiting epsteins manhattan massage parlour. Best of luck to her when the truth comes out.
Weird cluing for 28D. IVF is generally not done on frozen eggs. In the vast majority of cases, the eggs are ‚Äúfresh,‚Äù and the embryos are what get frozen.

Fun one today. Agree that the Northern region was a bit dubious with OYE MRNOODLE APA AIDY

Happy Christmas Eve!

I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs exactly true. One might be able to work out a Natick or two by guessing letters that might work phonetically, but if you didn‚Äôt know either crossing before and had to guess that‚Äôs still a Natick in my book!

@SP right, realistically one crossing had to be a vowel. The other crossing could only be  Y S D L. So 20 possible permutations, fewer than running the keyboard on a single square Natick with no phonetic clues.
@Steve L After I got my Gold Star, my first thought was to remember that Supreme Court transcripts always start with Oyez oyez. So oye being the Spanish spelling of the word made sense

And that, my friend, is why it's not a Natick.

@C

That's not my everyday view though - it's my family home where my father lives these days. It's located on the edge of one of Warsaw's major forests, in the shadow of its ancient oaks. We try to be eco-concious, so dad is letting the garden return to nature, in a way. The lawns have naturally transformed into meadows once he stopped mowing them, and he also does not rake any leaves. It's a haven for all sorts of animals throughout the year. Jorge the Lab is buried here under the wildflowers, one of which is (miraculously?) still in bloom in December as I'm writing this. I'm not a spiritual person but I still think it beautifully symbolic.
